title: U.S. Stock Futures Swing Higher
text:
By Avantika Chilkoti

U.S. stock futures turned higher Friday after the September jobs report showed employers added jobs at a steady pace and the unemployment rate hit a 50-year low.

Futures for the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.2% and had been off 0.3% ahead of the report.

The U.S. economy added 136,000 jobs in September, the Labor Department reported Friday. The jobless rate dropped to 3.5% in September from 3.7% in August, marking the lowest jobless rate since December 1969 when it also logged in at 3.5%.

Economists expected nonfarm payrolls were up 140,000 during the month, while the unemployment rate held steady at 3.7%.

Investors are parsing the report for clues on the health of the world's largest economy during a period of global turbulence.

The report follows a disappointing stretch of data. Earlier this week, fresh data showed that U.S. factory activity contracted for a second straight month and hit a 10-year low. Meanwhile, the pace of private-sector job creation has been muted.

Market watchers will comb the jobs data for signs of weakness, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy moving forward. Towering concerns about U.S. and global growth have led investors to ramp up bets that the Fed will slash rates again this year after their two cuts in the third quarter.

Later Friday, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will speak at a Fed Listens event in Washington.

At a Wall Street Journal event in New York on Thursday, Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida said the central bank will do what it takes to keep the longest period of U.S. economic expansion going. He added that the central bank takes each policy meeting "one at a time."

The recent concerns about the economy have led to a shaky week for stocks. In one sign of the jitters percolating markets this week, the S&P 500 recorded its first back-to-back drops of 1% of the year. The index also gave up its entire third-quarter gain.

Esty Dwek, a strategist at Natixis Investment Managers, said recent optimism that the global economy would pick up was fading. "The world has had, if not expectations at least hopes, that we would see a bottom, " Ms. Dwek said.

The yield on U.S. 10-year Treasurys edged u[ to 1.547% on Friday, from 1.531% on Thursday. Bond yields and prices move in opposite directions.

In premarket trading, HP shares dropped 3.8% after the computer hardware company said Thursday it would slash up to 9,000 jobs as part of its restructuring plan.

Elsewhere, the Stoxx Europe 600 rose 0.5%, after suffering heavy losses earlier in the week.

Among the biggest gainers was oil-and-gas giant, BP. The stock gained 1.1% after chief executive Bob Dudley said he would retire next year.

In Asia, Japan's Nikkei gained 0.3%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng fell 1.1% after the city's chief executive, Carrie Lam, said that from Saturday a ban would be implemented on wearing masks at public gatherings, with penalties of up to a year in jail and a fine.

The ban could escalate tensions between the government and protesters, leading to more violent confrontations, according to Francis Lun, chief executive at Geo Securities. "Investors should avoid Hong Kong-related stocks amid worsening social unrest," he said.

Stock markets in mainland China were closed on Friday.

In commodities, global oil benchmark Brent crude gained 0.7% to $58.09 a barrel. Gold edged up 0.1%.

Joanne Chiu and Gunjan Banerji contributed to this article.
